intro: Mentha lejeunei, commonly known as the Corsican mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and produces small, tubular flowers in shades of purple or white. Its leaves are oval-shaped, serrated, and emit a strong minty aroma when crushed. Mentha lejeunei is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb, though it is less common than other mint species.
